text: Investigation Introduction. Praise be to Allah who guided to His obedience and inspired, and taught man what he did not know. I ask Him for gratitude for what He has bestowed and favored, and for a good outcome by which He completes His blessings and concludes. Peace and blessings be upon Muhammad His Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and upon his family. To proceed... Here is a work among the works of one of the scholars of the ninth Hijri century in the science of Hadith Terminology. Its author mentioned in its opening that he collected its material from several books he listed; however, upon investigation, we find that his book is considered an abridgment of the book "Al-Khulasah fi Ma'rifat al-Hadith" by Sharaf al-Din al-Tibi (died 743 AH). Yes, he quoted others, but the majority of his book is summarized from the book of Al-Tibi, may Allah have mercy on him. The book is brief and concise, suitable as a text (Matn) in terminology. The author said in his preface: "These chapters are the texts of the fundamentals, and summaries of books on Hadith sciences. I wrote them in a concise manner so they are easy to recall, for this art has become strange." He said in his introduction: "This is a summary containing the minimum that is indispensable for a student of Hadith, indeed for every student of any type of legal sciences regarding the knowledge of Hadith sciences. I wrote it when I arrived in the city of Nishapur, at the suggestion of a group of scholars, refined, clarified, summarized, and purified from the books of the great Hafiz scholars and the Imams of the regions and reports." As for the author, he died in the first half of the ninth century, and information about him is scarce. I did not find anyone who mentioned him except later scholars like Ismail Pasha al-Baghdadi and Haji Khalifa. Did one of the scholars whose heritage has not yet been printed write a biography for him? Or is his case like...

text: ...some authors about whom only a little has been transmitted to us that does not satisfy?! Perhaps what has not been printed of our ancestors' books will unveil and answer many questions of this kind. I investigated his treatise based on two manuscripts, close in time to the author. My plan was as follows: I transcribed the text from Copy (A) and reconciled it with the two copies. I attributed the quotes in the treatise to their sources. I referenced the Hadiths, clarifying their ruling regarding authenticity and weakness. And I created an index for the sources. In conclusion... whatever success there is, it is purely a favor from Him, Glory be to Him, and whatever error there is, mistakes are a trait of humans. Sufficient for me is the saying of the first one: "I do not absolve myself, for I am human... I forget and err as long as fate does not protect me. And you see no excuse more fitting for one who errs... than to say, admitting: Indeed, I am human." And our final prayer is that praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds, and may Allah bless and grant peace to Muhammad, his family, and his companions. Written by Amr Abd al-Azim al-Huwaini. text: Biography of the Author. He is: Abu Muhammad Jalal bin Muhammad bin Ubayd Allah al-Qayini, al-Bukhari, al-Harawi. Died in the year 838 AH. I did not find a biography for him except what Ismail Pasha al-Baghdadi mentioned (1), where he said: "Al-Qayini, Muhammad bin Abdullah Jalal al-Din al-Qayini - Qayin is after the Alif, a Yaa with two dots below and a Nun, a town between Tabas and Nishapur - by birth, and al-Nasafi by residence, who died in Herat in the year 838 (eight hundred and thirty-eight). He has: 'Ishraqat al-Usul' in the Hadiths of the Prophet, peace be upon him." He added in "Idah al-Maknun" (2): "Al-Hanafi". And Haji Khalifa said (3): "'Ishraqat al-Usul' in the Hadiths of the Messenger. An abridgment in the principles of Hadith. By Jalal bin Muhammad al-Qayini." His name appeared at the beginning of Copy (A) as: "Jalal bin Muhammad bin Ubayd Allah al-Qayini by birth, al-Bukhari by origin, and al-Harawi by residence and earning." And at the beginning of Copy (B): "Abu Muhammad Jalal bin Muhammad bin Ubayd Allah al-Qayini by birth, al-Bukhari by origin, and al-Harawi by earning and residence."

text: Abu Ali al-Bakri said (1): "Al-Qayini is attributed to the town of Qayin, from the works of Tabas, between Nishapur and Isfahan." As for his teachers, I only found two mentioned in this book of ours, and they are: Imam Ibn al-Jazari. And Imam Husam al-Din Muhammad bin Jalal al-Ubaydi. As for his writings, he mentioned during this book of ours, in the section on fabricated Hadith, a book of his titled "Lawami' al-Usul" (The Shining Lights of Principles). I found another work for him besides these two, which is: "Sharh Nisab al-Sibyan" (Explanation of the Syllabus for Boys), a manuscript of which exists at the Institute of Manuscripts in Baku, Azerbaijan.

text: Description of Manuscripts. I relied on two manuscripts for the investigation of this treatise, and here is their description: The First Copy: From the holdings of the Al-Zahidiyah Treasury, owned by Sheikh Hafiz Thana'ullah al-Zahidi al-Pakistani, bearing his seal. It consists of 31 folios, each folio has two sides, each side has 15 lines. It states in its colophon: "This noble copy titled 'Ishraqat al-Usul fi Ilm Hadith al-Rasul' was transcribed by the weak servant in need of Allah the Rich: Muhammad bin Abd al-Rahman al-Najhi, may Allah forgive him, his parents, and all believing men and women, on Friday the fourteenth of Jumada al-Akhira in the year eight hundred and seventy-five." I symbolized it with (A). The Second Copy: From the holdings of the Gazi Husrev-beg Library in Sarajevo, under number (4429). It consists of 26 folios, each folio has two sides, each side has 19 lines. neither the name of its scribe nor the date of its transcription is mentioned. I symbolized it with (B).

It was said: He should vocalize everything for the sake of the beginner and the non-expert. His care for adjusting confused names of narrators should be greater because it is pure transmission. It is recommended to adjust the problematic parts (4/A) in the text, and clarify it in the margin because it is more eloquent. He should realize the letter forms and not write them in a suspended style (Ta'liq), nor make it thin to lighten its load in travel, for handwriting is a sign, so the best of it is the clearest (1). Chapter Three: On writing the Prayer, Salutation, Pleasure, and Mercy. The writer of Hadith must maintain writing the Prayer and Salutation upon the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and upon his family and companions, by the number of Allah's words and His kindnesses whenever he writes it. He should not tire of repeating it even if it is not in the original. Whoever neglects that is deprived of a great fortune. He should also pray with his tongue, peace be upon him, whenever he writes it. Likewise, expressing pleasure (Radiya Allahu anhu) and mercy (Rahimahullah) for the Companions and Scholars. It is disliked to restrict oneself to the Prayer without the Salutation, or vice versa (2). [Thus said Imam Taqi al-Din Ibn al-Salah, and others] (3). [Our Sheikh the Imam, the Traveler of the Earth, the Musnid of the World Muhammad bin] (4) Al-Jazari [may Allah Almighty perpetuate his blessings] (5) said in his "Bidayah": "There is a view on this." I heard it [from his words] (6) as well.

Al-Hakim said: It is what its chain connects raised (Marfu') to the Prophet, peace be upon him. Al-Muttasil (Connected): Also called Al-Mawsul. It is everything whose chain is connected and each one of its narrators heard it from the one above him, whether raised (Marfu') to the Prophet, peace be upon him, or stopped (Mawquf) at someone else. Al-Marfu' (Raised): It is what is attributed to the Prophet, peace be upon him, specifically, of word, action, or approval, whether connected or interrupted. This is the famous view. The difference has appeared from this between Musnad, Muttasil, and Marfu'. For the Muttasil may be Marfu' or non-Marfu'. And the Marfu' may be Muttasil or non-Muttasil. As for the Musnad according to Al-Hakim's view, it should be Muttasil Marfu'.

text: Al-Mu'an'an: Is that in whose chain it is said 'So-and-so from (An) so-and-so'. Al-Mu'allaq (Suspended): Is what has one or more omitted from the beginning of its chain, like Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, saying: Nafi' said, or Malik said, Ibn Umar said, or the Prophet, peace be upon him, said. Al-Afrad (Singulars): It is two types: One: Singular regarding all narrators. The second: Singular in relation to a direction, like saying: The people of Mecca and the people of Medina were unique in it. Al-Mudraj (Interpolated): It is types. One: What is interpolated into the Hadith from the speech of some of its narrators, so the one after him narrates it connected, creating the illusion it is from the Hadith. Second: That he has two texts with two chains, or part of a text with a chain other than its chain, so he narrates them together with one chain. Third: That he hears a Hadith from a group differing in its chain or text, so he inserts their narration based on agreement and does not mention the difference. Intentionality by any of the three is forbidden. Al-Mashhur (Famous): Is what is widespread among the people of Hadith specifically not others, or among them and others, like the Hadith: Actions are by intentions.

text: Al-Gharib (Strange) and Al-Aziz (Rare/Strong): Al-Gharib: Is what a just, precise narrator whose Hadith is collected and accepted is unique in narrating. If two or three narrate it, it is called Aziz. If a group narrates it, it is called Mashhur. Among the Afrad (Singulars) are those which are not Gharib, like Singulars attributed to regions. Al-Musahhaf (Distorted): Is a change of word or meaning. The verbal (12/A) is either distortion of sight or hearing, and it may be in the chain or the text. This is a magnificent art realized only by the skillful Hafiz scholars; Al-Daraqutni and Al-Khattabi are among them, and they have useful writings on it. Al-Musalsal (Patterned): Is what the men of its chain follow in succession upon its narration in a specific description or state, either in the narrator verbally like the Hadith of the Oath, or in action like the Hadith of interlacing hands, or in narration like the Musalsal by agreement of narrators' names and their fathers' names (1). Ziyadat al-Thiqah (Addition of the Trustworthy): It is types: One: That it occurs contradictory to what other trustworthy narrators reported. The ruling of this is rejection like the Shadh (Irregular). Second: That there is no contradiction or opposition at all to what others reported, like the Hadith whose full narration a trustworthy narrator is unique in reporting, and he does not address in it what others reported with opposition at all. This is accepted, and Al-Khatib reported the consensus of scholars on it.

Al-Khatib said (1): The doctrine of the majority of jurists and people of Hadith is that the addition from a trustworthy narrator is accepted if he is unique in it. Al-I'tibar (Consideration) by Follow-ups (Mutaba'at) and Witnesses (Shawahid): These are matters by which they recognize the condition of the Hadith. Al-I'tibar is looking into (12/B) the condition of the Hadith: was its narrator unique in it or not? Is he known or not? The method of I'tibar in reports is to say for example: Hammad bin Salamah narrated from Ayyub, from Ibn Sirin, from Abu Hurairah, from the Prophet, peace be upon him. So if it is seen that Hammad narrated it and was not followed up on it, then one looks: did a trustworthy narrator other than Ayyub narrate it from Ibn Sirin? If that is not found, then a trustworthy narrator other than Ibn Sirin narrated it from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him? Otherwise, a Companion other than Abu Hurairah narrated it from the Prophet, peace be upon him? So whichever of that is found, it is known by it that the Hadith has a basis; otherwise, no. The Mutaba'ah (Follow-up): Is that someone other than Hammad narrates it from Ayyub. This is the Complete Follow-up. Or someone other than Ayyub from Ibn Sirin. Or someone other than Ibn Sirin from Abu Hurairah. Or someone other than Abu Hurairah from the Prophet, peace be upon him. All this is called Incomplete Follow-up due to its distance. Al-Hakim in Al-Madkhal calls the Follow-up a Witness (Shahid). And the Witness: Is to narrate a Hadith with the meaning of a Hadith, not its wording.

text: Al-Mu'allal (Defective): Know that knowledge of the defects (Ilal) of Hadith is among its most majestic and precise sciences. Only people of expertise and penetrating understanding enable it. They are hidden, ambiguous causes that impugn it. The Mu'allal Hadith: Is that in which a factor impugning its authenticity is discovered, although its appearance suggests safety from it. Al-Mudallas (Concealed): What its defect is hidden. It is two types: One: What occurs in the Chain (Isnad), which is to narrate from one he met (15/B) or was contemporary with what he did not hear from him, creating the illusion he heard it from him. Second: What occurs in the Sheikhs, which is to narrate a Hadith from the Sheikh which he heard, so he names him, or gives him a Kunya (nickname), [or attributes him] (1), or describes him with what he is not known by so that he is not recognized. The first is very disliked (Makruh), and they differed on the narration of one known for it. As for the second, its matter is lighter, and the dislike varies in it according to the purpose driving it. text: Al-Maqlub (The Inverted): It is when a famous hadith from one narrator is attributed to another narrator so that people desire it due to its rarity. For example, a hadith famous from Salim is attributed to Nafi', so that it becomes rare and desirable thereby. It is narrated that Al-Bukhari came to Baghdad, so a group of Hadith scholars gathered and took one hundred hadiths and inverted their texts (Matn) and chains (Isnad). They assigned the text of this chain to another chain, and the chain of this text to another text. Then they attended his gathering and presented them to him. When they finished presenting them, he turned to them and returned (16/a) every text to its [correct] chain, and every chain to its [correct] text, so they acknowledged his superiority (1). Al-Mawdu' (The Fabricated): It is the invented [report], and it is the worst type of weak hadith and the vilest of its categories. It is not permissible to narrate it while knowing it [is fabricated] for any purpose whatsoever, unless its status is explained. This is unlike other types of weak hadith whose truthfulness is inwardly possible; for it is permissible to narrate them in matters of encouragement (Targhib) and warning (Tarhib) without restriction or explanation. Fabrication is recognized by signs explained in lengthy works, and I have explained some of them in 'Lawami' al-Usul'. These are twelve types specific to the weak hadith.

Integrity in him means: being a Muslim, mature, sane, free (16/b) from causes of immorality (Fisiq) and acts that destroy dignity (Muru'ah). Precision means: being [alert] (4), a memorizer if he narrates from memory, precise in his book if he narrates from it, and aware of what alters the meaning if he narrates by meaning. Being male, free [from slavery], knowing Fiqh or rare words, eyesight, or number [of witnesses] are not conditions.

text: Second: Integrity is known by the explicit designation of two just witnesses or by widespread fame (Istifadah). General endorsement (Ta'dil) is accepted without mentioning the reason according to the correct view, while criticism (Jarh) is not accepted unless it is explained. Criticism and endorsement regarding narrators are established by the statement of one person according to the correct view, though it is said: two are required, like testimony. If criticism and endorsement coincide regarding a person, criticism takes precedence. Third: The narration of one known for carelessness in hearing or conveying hadith is not accepted, such as one who sleeps during the hearing, or is distracted from it, or narrates not from a corrected original, or one known to accept prompting (Talqin) in hadith without [referencing] books or memory, or for frequent absent-mindedness if he does not narrate from a correct original, or one whose narrations contain many anomalies (Shadh) and rejected reports (Munkar). The narration of one whose state is unknown (Majhul al-Hal) outwardly and inwardly is not accepted. The chosen view is accepting the narration of one whose integrity is unknown inwardly but not outwardly, and this is the 'Mastur' (veiled). The narration of one who is unknown in person (Majhul al-Ain) is not accepted, which is anyone whom the scholars do not know, and whose hadith is not known except through a single narrator. Most of the early Hadith scholars call it 'Presentation' ('Ard), because the reader presents it to the Sheikh, whether he reads it himself or another reads while he hears, and whether he reads from a book or from his memory, and whether the Sheikh has memorized it or not, provided he holds his original copy, or a trustworthy person holds it. It is a valid narration by consensus, contrary to some who are not counted. [They differed on whether reading to the Sheikh is equal to hearing from his wording in merit, or above it, or below it? text: The Third View: That it is permissible to use 'Akhbarana' without restriction, but not 'Haddathana'. This is the school of Al-Shafi'i and his companions, Muslim, and the majority of the people of the East, and it is the common prevalent practice now. The Third Method: Abstract License (Al-Ijazah Al-Mujarradah). It has types: First: The highest of them, [a license from a specific person to a specific person, such as: 'I license you Sahih Al-Bukhari' for example] (1). The correct view according to the majority of scholars of Hadith and Fiqh is the permissibility of narrating and the [obligation] (2) of acting upon it. Second: A license from a specific person for a non-specific thing, like saying: 'I license you my heard materials or my narrations.' The majority hold the permissibility of narration by it and the obligation of action. Third: General license, like saying: 'I license the Muslims', or 'those who caught my time.' Al-Khatib permitted it absolutely. Fourth: License to an unknown person, or for an unknown thing. This is an invalid license (19/b) with no benefit. Fifth: Suspended license, such as: 'I license whomever So-and-so wills', or 'If Zayd wills the licensing of someone, I license him.' The apparent view is that it is not valid. Qadi Abu al-Tayyib gave a fatwa to this effect. Abu Ya'la Ibn al-Farra al-Hanbali and Ibn Amrus al-Maliki said: It is valid. Sixth: License to a non-existent person, like saying: 'I license whoever is born to So-and-so.' There is a disagreement regarding it. Al-Khatib permitted it and narrated it from Ibn al-Farra and Ibn Amrus. Qadi Abu al-Tayyib and Ibn al-Sabbagh invalidated it, and that is the correct view.

The correct view held by the majority and the investigators is preventing that, and restricting it to a phrase that indicates license, such as 'Haddathana Ijazatan' (He narrated to us by license), (20/b) or 'Munawalatan' (by handing over), or 'Idhnan' (by permission), or 'Ajazani' (He licensed me), or 'Nawalani' (He handed me), and similar phrases. The Fifth Method: Correspondence (Mukatabah): It is writing his heard material for an absent or present person in his handwriting, or authorizing its writing. It is also of two types: Coupled with License, and bare of it. The one coupled with License is like Munawalah coupled with it in validity and strength. As for the bare one, many early and late scholars permitted it. The expression for it is: 'Kataba ilayya fulan' (So-and-so wrote to me), or 'Akhbarani fulan kitabatan' (So-and-so informed me by writing). The Sixth Method: Notification (I'lam). It is when the Sheikh informs the student that this book is his narration or hearing, limiting it to that. Many scholars of Hadith, Usul, and Fiqh permitted narration by it. The Seventh Method: Bequest (Wasiyyah). It is when a narrator, upon his death or travel, bequeaths a book he narrates to a person. Some of the Salaf permitted the legatee to narrate that from the testator like I'lam. (21/a) The correct and right view is that it is not permissible. I have written something about it at the beginning of the book. There remain chapters: First: Discussion on Correction (Tashih), Indication of Weakness (Tamrid), and Tadbib (Marking). This is the concern of the [meticulous ones] (2). Tashih: is writing 'Sahh' (Correct) over speech that is correct in narration and meaning but is prone to doubt or disagreement. Tadbib: sometimes also called Tamrid, is extending a line starting like the head of the letter 'Sad' over something established in transmission but corrupt in wording or meaning, or weak, or incomplete. Among the incomplete is the place of Irsal (omission of the companion) or Inqita' (disconnection). Perhaps some of them limited the correction mark to (21/b) the 'Sad', so it resembled the 'Dabbah'. Second: It became dominant among Hadith scribes to limit 'Haddathana' and 'Akhbarana' to symbols, and it became so common that it is not hidden. They write for 'Haddathana': 'Athna', or 'Na', or 'Dana'. And for 'Akhbarana': 'Abna', or 'Ana', or 'Rana'. If a hadith has two or more chains, they write 'Ha' (H) when switching from one chain to another. They said: We have received no explanation of its matter from those who preceded, but some Huffaz wrote 'Sahh' in one place, indicating it is his symbol. It is said: It stands for 'Tahwil' (Transition) from one chain to another. It is said: It is from 'Haylulah' (Intervention) because it intervenes between the two chains. text: The Sixth Type: On Titles (Al-Alqab). The Seventh Type: The Similar and Different (Al-Mukhtalif wa Al-Mu'talif) (1). This is a majestic art; ignorance of it is ugly for people of knowledge, especially people of Hadith. Whoever does not know it, his mistakes multiply. It is what corresponds in writing, i.e., its form is the same, but differs in pronunciation. Like: Sallâm, all are emphasized (with Shaddah) except five: the father of Abdullah bin Salam the Companion, Muhammad bin Salam the Sheikh of Al-Bukhari, Salam bin Muhammad Al-Maqdisi, Salam the grandfather of Muhammad bin Abdul Wahhab bin Salam Al-Jubba'i the Mu'tazilite, and Salam bin Abi al-Huqayq. The Eighth Type: The Agreed and Separated (Al-Muttafiq wa Al-Muftariq) (2). It is what agrees in writing and pronunciation but the named persons are different. Al-Khatib has a book on it. Like Al-Khalil bin Ahmad; there are six, the first of whom is the teacher of Sibawayh. The Ninth Type: What is composed of the two types. It is when their names agree and correspond, but the names of their fathers or lineages differ, or vice versa. Al-Khatib has a good book on it, (26/b) he named it: 'Talkhis al-Mutashabih fi al-Rasm'. Like: Musa bin 'Ali, with Fatha on the 'Ayn, there are many. And Musa bin 'Ulay, with Damma on the 'Ayn. And Muhammad bin Abdullah Al-Mukharrimi, with Damma on the Mim, Fatha on the Kha, and Kasra on the emphasized Ra; a famous Muhaddith attributed to Al-Mukharram in Baghdad. And Muhammad bin Abdullah Al-Makhrami, with Fatha on the Mim, Sukun on the Kha, and light (non-emphasized) Fatha on the Ra; he narrated from Al-Shafi'i.

text: The Tenth Type: Those similar in Name and Father's Name, distinguished by advancement and delay [in order]. Like: Al-Walid bin Muslim, and Muslim bin Al-Walid. The Eleventh Type: Who is attributed to other than his father. Like: Abu Ubaidah Ibn al-Jarrah, attributed to his grandfather, and his father's name is Abdullah. The Twelfth Type: Attributes (Nisab) contrary to their apparent meaning. Like: Abu Masud Al-Badri; he settled in Badr and was attributed to it, but he did not witness its battle. The Thirteenth Type: Unique Names. Like: Jubayb with Damma on the Jim. The Fourteenth Type: Who is mentioned with different names and descriptions. This is an art much needed to identify Tadlis (obfuscation). Abdul Ghani bin Sa'id Al-Misri and others wrote on it. The Fifteenth Type: Knowledge of (27/a) the Mawali (Clients/Freedmen) (1). The most important part is knowing the Mawali attributed to tribes generally, like So-and-so Al-Qurashi while he is their client (Mawla). Then among them are clients by emancipation, and clients by Islam, like Al-Bukhari the Imam, [client] (2) of the Ju'fis by the loyalty of Islam. And among them are clients by alliance (Hilf), like Malik bin Anas the Imam; he and his clan are clients of Taym Quraysh by alliance.

text: The Sixteenth Type: Knowledge of Ambiguous Names (Al-Mubhamat) (1). Abdul Ghani bin Sa'id wrote on it, then Al-Khatib, then others. Qadi Ibn Jama'ah said (2): The one who compiled the most on it, to my knowledge, is Ibn Bashkuwal Al-Maghribi. An example is like the hadith of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them: That a man said: O Messenger of Allah, is Hajj every year? The Seventeenth Type: Knowledge of Trustworthy (Thiqat) and Weak (Du'afa) Narrators (3). This type is [among] (4) the greatest and most important types of Hadith sciences; it is by which the Sahih is distinguished from the Da'if. There are many works on it: Some are dedicated to Weak narrators, like the book of Al-Bukhari, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Uqayli, Al-Daraqutni, and others. Some are dedicated to Trustworthy narrators, like 'Kitab al-Thiqat' by Ibn Hibban. And some are combined, like the History (27/b) of Al-Bukhari, Ibn Abi Khaythama, and Ibn Abi Hatim. Jarh (Criticism) and Ta'dil (Endorsement) were permitted to safeguard the Sharia. The Eighteenth Type: Those who became confused (Khallata) among the Trustworthy. This is an important art; no specific work is known for it, though it deserves one.

text: Conclusion. The weak servant, lover of Hadith and its people, may Allah forgive him, says: These chapters are the texts of the principles and the summaries of the books of Hadith sciences. I wrote them with brevity to facilitate their recall, for this art has become strange. I read to our Sheikh, the Imam, the Allamah, our Master Husam al-Din Muhammad bin the Ascetic Sheikh Jalal al-Ubaydi, in the beginning of the book 'Ulum al-Hadith' by Al-Hakim Abu Abdullah Al-Naysaburi, may Allah have mercy on him, (29/b) Al-Hakim said (1): 'When I saw that innovations in our time had multiplied, and people's knowledge of the principles of Sunan had decreased, despite their persistence in writing reports and their great pursuit of them with neglect and heedlessness, this called me to compile a light book containing the mention of types of Hadith sciences.'
